attributes.title: First line treatment in transplant-eligible multiple myeloma: A systematic review and network meta-analysis

q1.value: First line treatment in transplant-eligible multiple myeloma: A systematic review and network meta-analysis

q3.value:
Main QUESTION: What is the most effective first-line therapy for patients with untreated/newly diagnosed multiple myeloma who are eligible for autologous stem-cell transplantation?

Question in PICO framework:
P: newly diagnosed/untreated multiple myeloma patients eligible for autologous stem-cell transplantation
I&C first-line therapies for multiple myeloma
O: overall survival (OS), progression-free survival (PFS)

q4.value: Network meta-analyses are an extension of the classical pairwise meta-analyses and they allows us to  statistically compare multiple interventions based on both head-to-head comparisons within trials and indirect comparisons across trials. Hypotheses are not pre-specified. We will build networks based on the data available.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A Bayesian method will be used to perform pairwise meta-analyses and network meta-analyses. Only randomized-controlled studies are eligible for enrollment.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
In the first reviewing stage, two reviewers will read the titles and decide whether a record is relevant to this review based on their common agreement.
In the second stage, abstracts of these selected studies will be assessed by two reviewers independently. Any disagreement will be resolved by a third reviewer.
In the last stage of selection, full-text of selected abstracts will be assessed by two reviewers independently. Any disagreement will be resolved by a third reviewer.
The following data will be extracted in standardized tables by one reviewer and verified by a second: first author, title, year of publication, study design, number of patients, age, gender distribution, number of patients at risk for each evaluated outcome.
In case of survival (number of patients at risk), if raw data is not available, we will contact authors of the study or estimate the value from the Kaplan-Meier curve, if applicable.

q13.value: Not applicable, the analyzes will be conducted on the available data for each outcome.

question.value:
Primary outcomes: 12-month, 24-month, 36-month, and 48-month overall survival (OS); 12-month, 24-month, 36-month, and 48-month progression-free survival (PFS)
Secondary outcomes: -

Data will be gathered on number of patients at risk for all outcomes clinical as pre-specified above.
Measures will be combined into Relative Risk (RR).

A Bayesian method will be used to perform pairwise meta-analyses and network meta-analyses. All the analyses will be carried out under a random effect model. To ensure interpretability of the NMA results (pooled of direct and indirect data), we will present the geometry of the network, the results with probabilistic statements, and estimates of interventions effects along with their corresponding 95 % CIs, as well as forest plots. Heterogeneity will be tested by χ² test and I² test. For ranking the interventions, we chose to use the surface under the cumulative ranking (SUCRA) curve, which provides a numerical summary of the rank distribution of each treatment. To check for publication bias, a visual inspection of funnel plots will be performed with Egger’s test.

attributes.title: Reduced versus standard antipsychotic dose for maintenance therapy in schizophrenia

q1.value: Standard versus reduced dose of antipsychotics for relapse prevention in schizophrenia

q3.value: By conducting a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials comparing different doses of antipsychotic maintenance therapy in stabilized individuals with schizophrenia, we will estimate the risk of relapse and other clinically relevant outcomes with reduced doses. Use of the lowest possible antipsychotic dose is desirable for long-term treatment due to cardio-metabolic side-effects and recommended by current guidelines. However, it is not clear to what extent dose-reduction affects the risk of relapse or a general worsening of psychotic symptoms. This question has been addressed in a prior meta-analysis from 2011 (Uchida et al. Schizophr Bull 2011;37:788–99), which relied considerably on clinical trials with first-generation antipsychotics. Treatment practices have changed substantially since, with a predominant use of second-generation antipsychotics and their long-acting injectable formulations, and an update incorporating more recent trials is warranted.

q4.value: A reduced dose of antipsychotics for maintenance therapy in schizophrenia is associated with an increased risk of relapse and treatment discontinuation.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials on adults with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder, with a minimum duration of 24 weeks, comparing 2 or more doses of the same antipsychotic, with one dose being below recommended maintenance doses.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
We will search the following databases, without language restrictions, from database inception:
- Embase (1947 - now)
- Medline (1946 - now)
- PsycINFO (1806 - now)
- Cochrane Library (1898 - now)

We will supplement the database searches with a manual review of reference lists in eligible studies and update the search before submission.

The general search strategy was built combining population and intervention (appendix 1). We did not include specific comparisons and outcomes as preliminary searches suggested that this approach would exclude potentially relevant references. The search terms consisted of a combination of subject headings and free text, which were identified from abstracts of known studies and database searches (appendix 2). Search results will be limited to clinical trials and human subjects using the validated search filters provided in appendix 2.

Relevant study types:
Randomized clinical trials (double-blind, single-blind or open-label)

Condition:
Schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder

Population:
Inclusion: Adults (≥18 years)
Exclusion: Adolescents (<18 years), first-episode psychosis, treatment-resistant schizophrenia, and acute phase/exacerbation of the illness.

Interventions and exposure:
Antipsychotic maintenance treatment including all currently used compounds (appendix 2).

Comparison:
Reduced versus standard doses, with reduced doses being defined as doses below the lower limit of recommended maintenance doses according to the International Consensus Study of antipsychotic dosing (Gardner et al. Am J Psychiatry 2010;167:686–93). For antipsychotics not included in the International Consensus Study, we refer to the individual prescribing information, or to the 95% effective dose reported in Leucht et al. (Am J Psychiatry 2019, doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2019.19010034), as the lower limit of effective maintenance doses. For studies including dose ranges, the mean or median dose is used to determine the relevant grouping.

Data extraction:
All identified studies will be independently assessed for eligibility by two reviewers using Covidence. Data extraction will be performed by two independent reviewers using a predetermined data extraction form. Any eligibility or data extraction issues will be solved through consensus or involvement of the senior author.

Quality assessment:
Quality assessment will be performed by two independent reviewers using the Cochrane Risk of Bias tool, version 2 (Sterne et al. BMJ. 2019;366:l4898). Disparities in a single item or overall quality assessment will be solved through consensus or involvement of the senior author.

q13.value: We aim to include all relevant studies regardless of time limits

question.value:
Main outcomes:
Relapse and all-cause discontinuation. If studies did not assess relapse separately, rehospitalization for psychiatric reasons was used as a proxy for relapse.

Additional outcomes:
Rehospitalization for psychiatric reasons, intolerability-related discontinuation, incident use of anticholinergics, and changes in psychopathology scores from baseline to follow-up (measured using the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale for schizophrenia (PANSS) (Kay et al. Schizophr Bull 1987;13:261–76.) and/or the Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS) (Overall  and Gorham. Psychol Rep. 1962;10:799–812)).

We will also collect basic study information on gender and age distribution among participants, as well as mean duration of illness if described.

Extracted data will be included in a random-effects meta-analysis calculating risk ratios with 95% confidence intervals for dichotomous outcomes and standardized mean differences (Hedges’ g) for continuous outcomes. The number needed to harm with 95% confidence intervals will be calculated for significant outcomes with heterogeneity below 50% as the inverse of the risk ratio.

Planned subgroup analyses:
We will conduct subgroup analyses for the following strata if they consist of ≥2 trials: 
- First- vs. second-generation antipsychotics
- Oral vs. long-acting injectable formulations
- Double-blind vs. single-blind or open-label trials

attributes.title: Improving Supportiveness of Interviewer using the Simulated Child Sexual Abuse Interviews

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Improving Supportiveness of Interviewer using the Simulated Child Sexual Abuse Interview

sample.value: We will recruit 80 participants aiming for 20 participants per condition.

analyses.value:
[Planned analyses] 
We will conduct separate three-factor mixed ANOVAs with feedback on OQ, feedback on SS, and time as independent variables for each of the dependent variables except for the proportion of the correctness of conclusions. Multiple comparisons of the groups at each level of time using Holm's method (Holm, 1979) will be conducted for all these dependent variables. 
We will conduct two-factor ANOVA with feedback on OQ and feedback on SS as independent variables for the proportion of the correctness of conclusions in the second and subsequent interviews.
[Expected effects] 
The main effects of feedback on OQ and time, and interaction between feedback on OQ and time will be significant for (1) the number of recommended questions, (2) the number of not recommended questions, and (3) the proportion of recommended questions. 
 The main effects of feedback on SS and time, and interaction between feedback on SS and time will be significant for (4) the number of supportive statements. 
The main effects of feedback on OQ, feedback on SS, and time, and interaction between feedback on OQ, feedback on SS, and time will be significant for (5) the number of relevant details, (6) the number of irrelevant details, and (7) the number of wrong details. 
For the Condition 2 and 4 compared to the Condition 1, multiple comparisons will show significantly (1) higher number of recommended questions, (2) lower number of not recommended questions, and (3) higher proportion of recommended questions as a function of the increasing of the number of interviews.
For the Condition 3 and 4 compared to the Condition 1, multiple comparisons will show significantly (4) higher number of supportive statements as a function of the increasing of the number of interviews.
For the Condition 2, 3 and 4 compared to the Condition 1, multiple comparisons will show significantly (5) higher number of relevant details, (6) higher number of irrelevant details, and (7) lower number of wrong details as a function of the increasing of the number of interviews.
The main effects of feedback on OQ and feedback on SS, and interaction between feedback on OQ and feedback on SS will be significant for (8) the proportion of the correctness of conclusions. 
(8) higher proportion of the correctness of conclusions will be obtained to the Condition 4,  Condition 2 and 3 and Condition 1, in that order.

outliers.value: Data of participants who do not conduct 4 interviews will be excluded from analyses.

dependent.value:
Questioning skill will be measured using the following measurement: 
(1) Number of recommended questions asked by the interviewer 
(2) Number of not recommended questions asked by the interviewer 
(3) Proportion of recommended questions asked by the interviewer 

Supportiveness will be measured using the following measurement: 
(4) Number of supportive statements used by the interviewer 

Interview quality will be measured using the following measurements: 
(5) Number of relevant details elicited from the avatars 
(6) Number of irrelevant details elicited from the avatars 
(7) Number of wrong details elicited from the avatars 
(8) Correctness of conclusions as to whether the interviewed avatars were abused. 

The increase of (1) and (3), and a decrease of (2) represents an improvement in interviewing skills. 
The increase of (4) represents an improvement of supportiveness. 
Increases of (5), (6), and (8), and a decrease of (7) represent an improvement of the interview quality. 

Each participant will conduct 4 interviews with different avatars. Each interview will last a maximum of 10 minutes, and participants will ask questions verbally to the avatar to elicit information for making a conclusion regarding the alleged CSA for the avatar. Also, participants will use supportive statements to decrease the reluctance of the avatar and increase the probability of eliciting more details.

conditions.value:
This study has a 2x2x4 mixed design based on the following 3 factors:
 - Feedback on Outcome and Question-type (OQ): Present vs. Not present (between subject)
 - Feedback on Supportive Statement (SS): Present vs. Not present (between subject)
 - Time: From 1st to 4th interviews (within-subjects) 
Outcome feedback: A description of what actually happened in the case 
Question-type feedback: Explanations about 2 recommended questions and 2 not recommended questions asked by the interviewer 
Supportive Statement feedback: Explanations about up to 2 supportive statements used by the interviewer 

Participants will be randomly assigned to the following 4 conditions:
 - Condition 1: Participants will conduct interviews without feedback
 - Condition 2: Participants will conduct interviews with feedback on OQ after each interview
 - Condition 3: Participants will conduct interviews with feedback on SS after each interview
 - Condition 4: Participants will conduct interviews with feedback on OQ and SS after each interview

hypothesis.value:
(1) Feedback improves questioning skills and results in the improvement of interview quality in simulated Child Sexual Abuse (CSA) interviews using avatars. 
(2) Feedback improves supportiveness and results in the improvement of interview quality in simulated CSA interviews using avatars. 
(3) Providing feedback simultaneously still improves both questioning skills and supportiveness and results in the improvement of interview quality in simulated CSA interviews using avatars.

q3.value: 戦後の天皇は、政治的な権限を奪われながらも、国民は天皇の発言に注目し続けている。天皇の発言は、政治性を帯びないように注意深く選択されているが、それにもかかわらず、政治的な含意をもつことが時にあり得る。戦後の平成の天皇（今の上皇）と今上天皇は、政治的なイデオロギーから考えるとリベラルだと見なされるが、これは天皇制という保守的な制度とは相容れない側面がある。天皇はこうした立場にあって発言をしているため、その発言内容の意図せざる二重性には注目されてしかるべきである。本研究は、こうした天皇の発言が表現の自由に対する人々の選好に与える影響をサーヴェイ実験の手法を用いて分析する。

q4.value:
本研究では、ヘイトスピーチと歴史文化に対するイベントを題材にし、実際の天皇の発言と組み合わせた実験刺激を用いて、表現の自由に対する人々の選好に天皇の発言が与える影響を分析する。
ヘイトスピーチと、たとえば、あいちトリエンナーレのようなイベントは、どちらも表現の自由と密接に関係しているが、イデオロギー的な側面から考えると、正反対の性質を帯びている。すなわち、ヘイトスピーチは、一般に右派（保守）が規制に反対し、左派（リベラル）が規制に賛成すると考えられるのに対し、あいちトリエンナーレのような表現に対しては、一般に左派（リベラル）が規制に反対し、右派（保守）が規制に賛成すると考えられる。まず、このようなテーマのフレームが表現の自由に与える影響を分析する。仮説は以下のようになる。

仮説1．ヘイトスピーチと歴史文化的イベントは、人々の表現の自由規制に反対の影響を与える。
ただし、どちらのテーマがより影響を受けるといった度合いの比較は、テーマ自体の対称性が完全に担保されていないため困難である。

これらに加えて、天皇の発言が表現の自由規制に与える影響を検証する。平成の天皇や今上天皇は、天皇制という歴史的な制度の中で、平和や平等といったリベラルな価値を訴え続けている。
こうした状況にあっては、天皇そのものに対する属人的な信頼と、天皇制という制度に対する信頼が区別して認識されていると考えられる。そして、こうした区別は、人々のイデオロギーとも関係していると考えられる。すなわち、左派（リベラル）は、天皇制という制度に対して、自由主義や平等主義といった観点や、戦前の天皇制を想起するため否定的だが、リベラルな発言をする天皇は支持している。その一方で、右派（保守）は、リベラルな発言を繰り返す天皇には否定的だが、天皇制という制度そのものは歴史的な観点から支持していると考えられる。したがって、以下のような仮説が検証される。

仮説2．左派（リベラル）は、リベラルな天皇という人を信頼し、右派（保守）は、天皇制という制度を信頼する

こうした仮説が支持され、天皇という人に対する信頼と、天皇制という制度に対する信頼が異なれば、天皇による実際の発言もイデオロギー的な観点から支持・不支持が決定されるはずである。リベラルな天皇の発言は左派（リベラル）が支持し、右派（保守）は支持しないと考えられる。これをテーマ設定と組み合わせると、以下のような仮説が検証される。

仮説3-1．言論の自由を支持するリベラルな天皇発言は、ヘイトスピーチ問題においては、右派（保守）が天皇の意図を誤解し、ヘイトスピーチへのお墨付きを得たと考え、ヘイトスピーチ規制反対を強める
仮説3-2．ただし、その発言の後に、朝鮮半島に対する天皇のリベラルな発言があると、規制反対が弱まる

仮説4．言論の自由を支持するリベラルな天皇発言は、歴史文化的イベントにおいては、左派（リベラル）が天皇の意見を支持し、過去の日本の歴史批判の規制反対を強める
仮説4-1.　さらに、その発言の後に、朝鮮半島に対する天皇のリベラルな発言があると、規制反対をさらに強める

実験では、テーマのランダマイズと天皇発言のランダマイズによって人々の表現の自由に対する規制支持への影響を分析する。テーマのランダマイズと天皇発言のランダマイズに加えて、placeboを含む全9群を以下のようにランダマイズする。

1:フレームなし＋専門家発言（統制・Placebo）
2:フレームなし＋天皇発言
3:フレームなし＋天皇発言＋韓国好意的発言
4:あいトリフレーム＋専門家発言
5:あいトリフレーム＋天皇発言
6:あいトリフレーム＋天皇発言＋韓国好意的発言
7:ヘイトフレーム＋専門家発言
8:ヘイトフレーム＋天皇発言
9:ヘイトフレーム＋天皇発言＋韓国好意的発言

テーマをランダマイズする文は以下のようになる。
---
⽇本では（①外国人に対する民族・人種差別的な言動・活動（ヘイトスピーチ／憎悪表現）が活発になっている問題を受けて、②日本の文化・歴史に対する否定的な表現を含む芸術作品が公営の施設・イベントで展示されていた問題を受けて、）公共の場所における表現の規制に関する議論が⾼まっています。あなたは、公共の場所における表現を政府・⾃治体が規制することに関してどのような意⾒をお持ちでしょうか。（ひとつだけ）
---
という質問に答えてもらい、
---
積極的に⾏われるべきである
必要があれば⾏われるべきである
⾏うべきか、⾏うべきでないか、どちらともいえない
できるだけ⾏われるべきではない
どんな場合であっても⾏われるべきではない
わからない
---
という選択肢を選んでもらい、その後に、発言をランダマイズする以下の群が続く。
---
あなたは、公共の場所における表現を政府・⾃治体が規制することに関して、（賛否）とお答えになりました。 この問題に対しては、様々な意⾒がありますが、（①政治・憲法学者の間では、言論の自由が保たれるということは、民主主義の基本であり、大変大切なことであると考えら／②現在の上皇陛下は、天皇として在位されていた時に「言論の自由が保たれるということは、民主主義の基礎であり大変大切なこと」（平成元年8月4日のお言葉）とお言葉を述べら／③現在の上皇陛下は、平成天皇だった時に「言論の自由が保たれるということは、民主主義の基本であり、大変大切なこと」とお言葉を述べられ、また「我が国が朝鮮半島の人々に多大の苦難を与えた一時期がありました。私は先年、このことにつき私の深い悲しみの気持ちを表明いたしました」（平成6年3月24日のお言葉）と）話されています。
---
この後に、もう一度質問を繰り返し、人々の態度変化を分析する。

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: 調査対象者は、オンライン上のクラウドソーシングサービスであるランサーズの登録者プールから、１８歳以上を条件として募集した。三浦・⼩林 (2016) によれば、クラウドソーシングサービスの登録者はネット調査のモニタに⽐べて、実験⽂や設問を読まないなど Satisficing と呼ばれる回答努⼒の最⼩限化 (Krosnick, 1991) を⾏いにくい。また、これまでの社会科学における実験で頻繁に利⽤されてきた⼤学⽣の実験参加者に⽐べて、⼈⼝統計、政治的⽴場、社会における位置付けなどの点から多様性が⾼いため、⼀般有権者の⾦融緩和政策選好についての実験を⾏う上で、より有⽤性が⾼いサンプルであると考えられる。ただし、クラウドソーシングサービスの登録者は⽇本の有権者⼈⼝からランダムに抽出されたサンプルではない。したがって、実験のトリートメント効果を超えた調査回答の絶対値について解釈を⼀般化する際には留意が必要である。

q13.value: 実験群１つにつき、約200人の回答者を割り当てた。

二標本間のｔ検定、重回帰分析（最小二乗法、ロジット）を使用して分析を行う。以下は、各分析モデルの独立変数（IV）、従属変数（DV)、統制変数（CV）である。

①ｔ検定： IV=実験群、DV=表現の自由規制選好（連続変数）
②最小二乗法：IV＝実験群、DV=表現の自由規制選好（連続変数）、CV＝性別、年齢、収入、教育程度、仕事の有無、政治知識量（事実認識設問の合計）、内閣支持、日本社会の平等認識、日本社会の同質性
②ロジット：IV＝実験群、DV=表現の自由規制選好（二値変数、1-3を1、その他を0）、CV＝性別、年齢、収入、教育程度、仕事の有無、政治知識量（事実認識設問の合計）、内閣支持、日本社会の平等認識、日本社会の同質性

registration_responses.q3: 戦後の天皇は、政治的な権限を奪われながらも、国民は天皇の発言に注目し続けている。天皇の発言は、政治性を帯びないように注意深く選択されているが、それにもかかわらず、政治的な含意をもつことが時にあり得る。戦後の平成の天皇（今の上皇）と今上天皇は、政治的なイデオロギーから考えるとリベラルだと見なされるが、これは天皇制という保守的な制度とは相容れない側面がある。天皇はこうした立場にあって発言をしているため、その発言内容の意図せざる二重性には注目されてしかるべきである。本研究は、こうした天皇の発言が表現の自由に対する人々の選好に与える影響をサーヴェイ実験の手法を用いて分析する。
registration_responses.q4:
本研究では、ヘイトスピーチと歴史文化に対するイベントを題材にし、実際の天皇の発言と組み合わせた実験刺激を用いて、表現の自由に対する人々の選好に天皇の発言が与える影響を分析する。
ヘイトスピーチと、たとえば、あいちトリエンナーレのようなイベントは、どちらも表現の自由と密接に関係しているが、イデオロギー的な側面から考えると、正反対の性質を帯びている。すなわち、ヘイトスピーチは、一般に右派（保守）が規制に反対し、左派（リベラル）が規制に賛成すると考えられるのに対し、あいちトリエンナーレのような表現に対しては、一般に左派（リベラル）が規制に反対し、右派（保守）が規制に賛成すると考えられる。まず、このようなテーマのフレームが表現の自由に与える影響を分析する。仮説は以下のようになる。

仮説1．ヘイトスピーチと歴史文化的イベントは、人々の表現の自由規制に反対の影響を与える。
ただし、どちらのテーマがより影響を受けるといった度合いの比較は、テーマ自体の対称性が完全に担保されていないため困難である。

これらに加えて、天皇の発言が表現の自由規制に与える影響を検証する。平成の天皇や今上天皇は、天皇制という歴史的な制度の中で、平和や平等といったリベラルな価値を訴え続けている。
こうした状況にあっては、天皇そのものに対する属人的な信頼と、天皇制という制度に対する信頼が区別して認識されていると考えられる。そして、こうした区別は、人々のイデオロギーとも関係していると考えられる。すなわち、左派（リベラル）は、天皇制という制度に対して、自由主義や平等主義といった観点や、戦前の天皇制を想起するため否定的だが、リベラルな発言をする天皇は支持している。その一方で、右派（保守）は、リベラルな発言を繰り返す天皇には否定的だが、天皇制という制度そのものは歴史的な観点から支持していると考えられる。したがって、以下のような仮説が検証される。

仮説2．左派（リベラル）は、リベラルな天皇という人を信頼し、右派（保守）は、天皇制という制度を信頼する

こうした仮説が支持され、天皇という人に対する信頼と、天皇制という制度に対する信頼が異なれば、天皇による実際の発言もイデオロギー的な観点から支持・不支持が決定されるはずである。リベラルな天皇の発言は左派（リベラル）が支持し、右派（保守）は支持しないと考えられる。これをテーマ設定と組み合わせると、以下のような仮説が検証される。

仮説3-1．言論の自由を支持するリベラルな天皇発言は、ヘイトスピーチ問題においては、右派（保守）が天皇の意図を誤解し、ヘイトスピーチへのお墨付きを得たと考え、ヘイトスピーチ規制反対を強める
仮説3-2．ただし、その発言の後に、朝鮮半島に対する天皇のリベラルな発言があると、規制反対が弱まる

仮説4．言論の自由を支持するリベラルな天皇発言は、歴史文化的イベントにおいては、左派（リベラル）が天皇の意見を支持し、過去の日本の歴史批判の規制反対を強める
仮説4-1.　さらに、その発言の後に、朝鮮半島に対する天皇のリベラルな発言があると、規制反対をさらに強める

attributes.title: Investigating Social and Psychological Development of Children with Epilepsy
attributes.description: In this study, we explore the social and psychological (and related factors) developmental process of children with epilepsy.

q1.value: Investigating the expressive language and cognitive development of bilingual and monolingual children with epilepsy and language delay in early childhood

q4.value:
The literature on the topic of the clinical sample is quite controversial. Accordingly, we hypothesized that:

1) There will be a language delay slope difference between monolingual and bilingual children according to their DENVER-II score (pre-test) and TIFALDI score (post-test). 
2) There will be a verbal comprehension index difference between monolingual and bilingual children according to their WISC-IV scores.
3) There will be a working memory index difference between monolingual and bilingual children according to their WISC-IV scores.
4) There will be a processing speed index difference between monolingual and bilingual children according to their WISC-IV scores.
5) There will be a perceptual reasoning index difference between monolingual and bilingual children according to their WISC-IV scores.
6) There will be a total WISC-IV score difference between monolingual and bilingual children.
7) There will be an executive function score difference between monolingual and bilingual children according to their Stroop Test scores.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q7.value:
The first author will know in which group all participants are and individual dependent variable scores, but will not work in method and result process.
The second author will run the analysis without knowing which group any of the participants are from.
The third author will only know if participants are experiencing language delay in early childhood and will not know other measurement and group information.
The fourth author will only know the single/dual language status of the participants, interpret the EEG and MR reports and take medical history but not know the participants' dependent variable measurements.
The fifth author will not know which group the participants are in, will only interpret EEG and MR reports and take the medical history.

question.value:
Mixed design, 1 factor (language delay) with two levels within-subjects (pre and post-test), and 1 factor (language) with 2 levels between-subjects (monolingual children and bilingual children) for RQ1.
Between subject design with 1 factor (language) monolingual children and bilingual children) from RQ2 to RQ7.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Only we had indicators of participants' pre-test scores. In detail, we scanned the data of children with epilepsy who were treated for epilepsy at Mersin University Child Neurology Clinic and who received the DENVER II test between February 2008 and February 2012 from the hospital database. As a result of the screening, we listed the children with epilepsy whose language development delay was detected as a result of the DENVER II test in the database [We did not include other developmental parameters in the evaluation. We randomly called the participants, learned their language situations (monolingual or bilingual) from their parents and invited the research by explaining the purpose of the research. We gave an appointment to the participants who agreed to participate in the research.]. We coded the language development delay times related to the language development sub-dimension obtained from the database as the language delay score (pre-test) of the participants.

question.value:
- Between the ages of 6 and 12 (within the time frame of the study)
- There was a delay in the language development sub-dimension of DENVER II test (please see the section of explanation of existing data)
- do not use more than two antiepileptics
- have no neurological or psychiatric chronic diagnosis other than epilepsy
- with no-lesionic epilepsy
- bilingual or monolingual children will be included in the research.

We scanned the data of children with epilepsy who were treated for epilepsy at Mersin University Child Neurology Clinic and who received the DENVER II test between February 2008 and February 2012 from the hospital database. As a result of the screening, we listed the children with epilepsy whose language development delay was detected as a result of the DENVER II test in the database. We did not include other developmental parameters in the evaluation. We randomly called the participants, learned their language situations (monolingual or bilingual) from their parents and invited the research by explaining the purpose of the research. We gave an appointment to the participants who agreed to participate in the research. 

Neurological examinations of children with epilepsy coming to the appointment will be done by pediatric neurologists (fourth and fifth author) and their neurological findings (EEG, MRI) will be evaluated. After the medical evaluation, the family and the child will be informed by the expert psychologist (first author) who will perform the tests, and written consent will be obtained from the child and the family. Stroop Test, WISC-IV, Turkish Expressive and Receptive Language Test (TIFALDI) tests will be applied to the children who agree to participate in the research to test the research questions. After the application of each test, 15 minutes will be given to rest the child and the researcher. The Stroop Test, WISC-IV and TİFALDİ tests will take approximately 180 minutes, with 15-minute breaks between each test.

attributes.title: Bullshitting Frequency Scale (BSF)
attributes.description: Construction and validation of self-report measure of everyday bullshitting.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: Based on recommendations by Nunnally (1978) for factor analysis, our goal is to recruit approximately 300 participants. This sample size also provides ample power to detect an effect of r = .20 at an alpha = .05

analyses.value: Bivariate correlation coefficients will be calculated between each of our DVs. We will also calculate partial correlations between each BSF subscale (controlling for the other subscale) and our remaining DVs. Finally, we will conduct factor analyses to test factor loadings for the alternate BSF items and to confirm the two-factor structure of the BSF.

outliers.value:
1) Participant data will be excluded for those respondents who fail attention checks (e.g., "I eat cement daily," and "I am paid bi-weekly by leprechauns"). 

2) Additionally, Google's reCAPTCHA v3 "bot detection" feature will be activated for the Qualtrics survery. This feature scores responses for each participant from 0 to 1. A score of greater than or equal to 0.5 means the respondent is likely a human. A score of less than 0.5 means the respondent is likely a bot. Participant data with scores of less than 0.5 will be excluded.

3) Based on recommendations from Chmielewski & Kucker (2019), we will also exclude data of any participants who provide unusual, implausible, or nonsensical comments to open-ended items on the Numeracy Scale such as single words that do not align with the question (e.g., “nice”, “good”), noticeably ungrammatical or nonsense phrases, and/or phrases that repeat portions of the question (e.g., “yes longest phrase”).

dependent.value:
Dependent variables include the following measures (DV is the calculated score for each measure): 

1) The Bullshitting Frequency Scale (BSF; Littrell, Risko, & Fugelsang, 2019). The scale contains two factors: 1) Persuasive bullshitting, and; 2) Evasive bullshitting. Mean scores will be calculated for each subscale as well as a mean score for the overall scale. 
2)  A bullshitting task designed specifically for this study. Participants will be presented with 4 vignettes. For each vignette, participants will be asked to rate how likely they would be to respond from a list of possible responses (truth, lie, bullshit). Mean scores will be calculated for each response type.
3) The Political Overclaiming Questionnaire (Dunlop et al., 2019) that contains 12 targets and six foils relating to the topic of politics and political concepts. Participants rate each item using a 3-point response scale from 0 ("I have never heard of this item...) to 2 ("I could talk intelligently to others about this item/concept"). Separate scores are calculated for hits (i.e., number of real items a person claims knowledge of) and false alarms (i.e., the number of fake/foil items a person claims knowledge of). 
4) An additional political overclaiming task will also be used, adapted from Study 3 of Dunlop et al. (2019). Participants are presented with 10 propositions, 3 of which are foils, which ask participants to rate whether the agree, disagree, or do not know enough about the proposition to have an opinion. For items rated agree or disagree, a text box appears which allows participants to write a short summary of their reasons for that response. Scores are calculated two ways, hits and false alarms, similar to the Political-OCQ. 

Additionally, as an exploratory analysis, word counts will be calculated for all items (real and foil) and used as a DV in correlational analyzes (as described above).

4) Cognitive ability will be measured using the General Risk and Numeracy Scale (Lipkus, Samsa, & Rimer, 2001), a 10-item test of numerical knowledge, and the Wordsum vocabulary test (Thorndike, 1942; Malhotra, Krosnick, & Haertel, 2007), a 10-item vocabulary test. Total correct scores for both scales will be summed. Those sums will then be added and divided by 2 to calculate a mean cognitive ability score.

conditions.value: All participants will be assigned to the same condition.

hypothesis.value: How are scores on the Bullshitting Frequency Scale (BSF) related to self-report measures of overclaiming and cognitive ability?  We will also compare correlations between BSF scores and responses to vignettes describing common social situations where one could respond by lying, bullshitting, or telling the truth. We will also test alternate wordings of four BSF items.

attributes.title: Affective incongruence in PTSD and resilience

q1.value: Do Implicit Measures of Affect Converge? Comparison of the IPANAT and the Disguised Mood Measure.

q2.value: Anna Semenchenko, McKenzie Lockett, Sander Koole

q3.value:
Only a part of emotional experience can be verbalized and communicated and partially captured by self-report measures (Scherer, 2009). Implicit measures of affect aim to capture non-verbalized conscious and unconscious representations of emotional experience as well as deal with the drawbacks of self-report measures (e.g., demand characteristics, evaluation apprehension, faking and introspective limits). The Implicit Positive and Negative Affect Test (IPANAT) (Quirin, Kazén, & Kuhl, 2009) is a measure of implicit affect that was developed in 2000s. The IPANAT asks the participants to rate the degree to which six artificial words sound like six mood adjectives (happy, cheerful, energetic, helpless, tense, and inhibited).  The measure is based on the idea that people misattribute their own affective states to the nonsense words, and that these misattributions provide an index of implicit affect. There is a good deal of evidence of its internal consistency, test-retest reliability, criterion, construct, and cross-cultural validity (Weil, Hernández, Suslow, & Quirin, 2019). 
Despite the strong empirical status of the IPANAT, there are reasons to develop additional measures of implicit affect. First, it is generally the case that each specific set of procedures invokes specific sources of measurement error. For instance, percentage of body fat can be measured with skinfold calipers or measures of body circumference. The accuracy of the skinfold caliper method depends on the skill of the person taking the measurements. The accuracy of body circumference measures depends on the body shape of the person. Thus, each measure of body fat has different sources of measurement error. The same is true for psychological measures. Therefore, a more accurate measurement can be formed by having multiple measures of the same construct.  Second, the IPANAT lends itself less well to repeated measurements of implicit affect in a single session. If the measure is repeated many times in a row, people may feel suspicious about what is being measured. Moreover, people may remember their ratings of words that were similar to the ones they rated before. 
To address these problems, we consider an implicit affect measure that was initially developed prior to the IPANAT, during the 1990s by Hass, Katz, Rizzo, Bailey, and Moore (1992). This measure was dubbed the ‘disguised measure of mood’ by the original authors. The disguised mood measure (DMM) is presented as a subliminal perception task, in which words are subliminally flashed on a computer screen and participants have to guess the affective meaning of the words. In reality, non-sense words are subliminally presented, so participants’ guesses are presumed to be based on misattribution of their inner affective state to the subliminal presentations. The rationale of the DMM is thus similar to that of the IPANAT, even though the DMM has not been systematically validated to the same extent as the IPANAT.

q4.value:
The general aim of the present study is to compare the IPANAT (Quirin et al., 2009) and the modified disguised mood measure (DMM-M) based on Hass et al. (1992) as different, but conceptually and methodologically closely related measures of implicit affect. The theoretical rationale of both measures is similar in that both are based on the principle of affect misattribution or affect infusion (Forgas, 1995), which presumes that that people’s inner affective states unconsciously bias the evaluation of unrelated objects in an affect-congruent manner. Accordingly, we predict that the IPANAT and the DMM-M will show substantial overlap. We expect both measures to be positively correlated at least in the medium range (r= .4 or higher). This prediction is predicated on the assumption that the measures will have similarly high reliabilities as in prior research (Cronbach’s alphas = .7 or higher).
A secondary aim of the present study is to test the validity of shorter versions of the IPANAT and the DMM-M. The newly created short versions ask the participants to rate positive and negative affect instead of six affective states. The shorter version of the DMM-M will allow to decrease participants’ fatigue in the studies with multiple iterations of an implicit affect measure. We predict, firstly, that the long and the short versions of the DMM-M will be highly correlated. Secondly, we expect the full and the short versions of IPANAT to be highly correlated. And lastly, we predict that the short version of the IPANAT and the short version of the DMM-M will show substantial overlap. This means that we expect both measures to be positively correlated at least in the medium range (r= .4 or higher).

question.value:
Implicit affect. The participants will complete the four measures of implicit affect. 

IPANAT Measures. The first measure of implicit affect, the IPANAT (Quirin et al., 2009) includes 36 items, which ask participants to rate the degree to which six artificial words (SAFME, VIKES, TUNBA, TALEP, BELNI, and SUKOV) sound like six mood adjectives (happy, cheerful, energetic, helpless, tense, and inhibited) on a four-point scale ( 1 = doesn’t fit at all, 4 = fits very well). The scores of the positive implicit affect scale will be calculated as a mean of happy, cheerful and energetic moods.  The scores of the negative implicit affect scale will be calculated as a mean of helpless, tense and inhibited moods. 
The second IPANAT measure, the short version of the IPANAT, includes 12 items, which ask participants to rate the degree to which the same six artificial words (SAFME, VIKES, TUNBA, TALEP, BELNI, and SUKOV) sound like two generalized mood adjectives (positive and negative) on a four-point scale ( 1 = doesn’t fit at all, 4 = fits very well). 

Modified Disguised Mood Measures. In the original disguised mood measure (Hass et al., 1992) a stimulus word (a non-sense word) is presented subliminally. After the subliminal presentation, one negative, one positive and two neutral words appear on the screen. The participants are asked to choose the word which best resembles the meaning of the subliminally presented word. We made two changes to the original procedure. Firstly, we replace subliminal presentation with a flicker. This will allow the measure to be used during online studies when the researcher has no control over internet connection and hardware. The theoretical basis for the procedure, i.e. affect misattribution, remains the same. Secondly, we changed the response format to parallel that of the IPANAT. As we equalized the response format, the essential difference between the IPANAT and the modified disguised mood measure is the stimulus: a non-sense word in the IPANAT and the flicker in the modified disguised mood measure.
For the DMM-M the following instructions will be presented on the screen “Previous studies have shown that people can “feel” the meaning of words even if these words are shown so fast that they cannot see them. In the present study, we want to learn more about this fascinating phenomenon. In a few moments, you will be shown words that are presented very fast on the computer screen. It is so fast you will probably not see a word at all. All you will see is a brief flicker on the screen. We will then ask you to judge the kinds of feelings that the word evoked in you. Please be sure to go with your gut feelings when judging the words.” In reality, there will be no subliminal presentation. After a string of asterisks, a blank screen will appear for 80 ms., followed by a string of asterisks.  After each flicker, the participants will rate the extent to which the word that just flashed feels like a mood on a four-point scale (1 = not at all, 4 = very well). Six flickers each followed by a question will be used to assess six moods (happy, cheerful, energetic, helpless, tense, and inhibited). The participants will complete the procedure for six non-words. The score of the positive implicit affect scale will be calculated as a mean of happy, cheerful and energetic moods.  The score of the negative implicit affect scale will be calculated as a mean of helpless, tense and inhibited moods. 
The short version of the DMM-M, follows the same procedure as the long version except for the following. The participants will rate the extent to which the word that flashed expresses not six moods, but two generalized moods (positive, negative) on a four-point scale ( 1 = not at all, 4 = very well). 

Explicit affect. The participants will complete two questionnaires of explicit affect. The first measure, explicit affect (short), parallels the short version of implicit affect measures by asking the participants to rate how positive and negative they feel right now.  The second measure, explicit affect, parallels the full version of implicit affect measures by asking the participants to rate how happy, cheerful, energetic, helpless, tense, and inhibited they feel right now. Four-point scale (1 = doesn’t fit at all, 4 = fits very well) will be used in both questionnaires. The score of the positive explicit affect scale in full version of the questionnaire will be calculated as a mean of happy, cheerful and energetic moods.  The score of the negative explicit affect scale will be calculated as a mean of helpless, tense and inhibited moods.

The following analyses will be performed:
•	Bivariate correlation coefficients for the positive affect scales of the following pairs of measures: the IPANAT and the DMM-M, the IPANAT (short) and the DMM-M (short) , the IPANAT and the IPANAT (short), the DMM-M and the DMM-M (short), explicit affect and the IPANAT, explicit affect and the DMM-M, explicit affect (short) and the IPANAT (short), explicit affect and the DMM-M (short), explicit affect and explicit affect (short). 
•	Bivariate correlation coefficients for negative affect scales of the same pairs of measures.
•	Regressions with short measure as independent variable and full measure as dependent variable to determine what percentage of variance in full measure is explained by variance in a short measure (one regression for each of the following: the IPANAT positive affect scale, the IPANAT negative affect scale, the DMM-M positive affect scale, the DMM-M negative affect scale, the measure of the explicit negative affect and the measure of explicit positive affect).
•	Cronbach’s alpha for positive affect scale and negative affect scale for each of the four implicit measures.

q22.value: The participants who failed at least one of the two attention checks or replied that we shouldn’t use their data because they were not paying attention, will be excluded from the analysis.

registration_responses.q17.question:
Implicit affect. The participants will complete the four measures of implicit affect. 

IPANAT Measures. The first measure of implicit affect, the IPANAT (Quirin et al., 2009) includes 36 items, which ask participants to rate the degree to which six artificial words (SAFME, VIKES, TUNBA, TALEP, BELNI, and SUKOV) sound like six mood adjectives (happy, cheerful, energetic, helpless, tense, and inhibited) on a four-point scale ( 1 = doesn’t fit at all, 4 = fits very well). The scores of the positive implicit affect scale will be calculated as a mean of happy, cheerful and energetic moods.  The scores of the negative implicit affect scale will be calculated as a mean of helpless, tense and inhibited moods. 
The second IPANAT measure, the short version of the IPANAT, includes 12 items, which ask participants to rate the degree to which the same six artificial words (SAFME, VIKES, TUNBA, TALEP, BELNI, and SUKOV) sound like two generalized mood adjectives (positive and negative) on a four-point scale ( 1 = doesn’t fit at all, 4 = fits very well). 

Modified Disguised Mood Measures. In the original disguised mood measure (Hass et al., 1992) a stimulus word (a non-sense word) is presented subliminally. After the subliminal presentation, one negative, one positive and two neutral words appear on the screen. The participants are asked to choose the word which best resembles the meaning of the subliminally presented word. We made two changes to the original procedure. Firstly, we replace subliminal presentation with a flicker. This will allow the measure to be used during online studies when the researcher has no control over internet connection and hardware. The theoretical basis for the procedure, i.e. affect misattribution, remains the same. Secondly, we changed the response format to parallel that of the IPANAT. As we equalized the response format, the essential difference between the IPANAT and the modified disguised mood measure is the stimulus: a non-sense word in the IPANAT and the flicker in the modified disguised mood measure.
For the DMM-M the following instructions will be presented on the screen “Previous studies have shown that people can “feel” the meaning of words even if these words are shown so fast that they cannot see them. In the present study, we want to learn more about this fascinating phenomenon. In a few moments, you will be shown words that are presented very fast on the computer screen. It is so fast you will probably not see a word at all. All you will see is a brief flicker on the screen. We will then ask you to judge the kinds of feelings that the word evoked in you. Please be sure to go with your gut feelings when judging the words.” In reality, there will be no subliminal presentation. After a string of asterisks, a blank screen will appear for 80 ms., followed by a string of asterisks.  After each flicker, the participants will rate the extent to which the word that just flashed feels like a mood on a four-point scale (1 = not at all, 4 = very well). Six flickers each followed by a question will be used to assess six moods (happy, cheerful, energetic, helpless, tense, and inhibited). The participants will complete the procedure for six non-words. The score of the positive implicit affect scale will be calculated as a mean of happy, cheerful and energetic moods.  The score of the negative implicit affect scale will be calculated as a mean of helpless, tense and inhibited moods. 
The short version of the DMM-M, follows the same procedure as the long version except for the following. The participants will rate the extent to which the word that flashed expresses not six moods, but two generalized moods (positive, negative) on a four-point scale ( 1 = not at all, 4 = very well). 

Explicit affect. The participants will complete two questionnaires of explicit affect. The first measure, explicit affect (short), parallels the short version of implicit affect measures by asking the participants to rate how positive and negative they feel right now.  The second measure, explicit affect, parallels the full version of implicit affect measures by asking the participants to rate how happy, cheerful, energetic, helpless, tense, and inhibited they feel right now. Four-point scale (1 = doesn’t fit at all, 4 = fits very well) will be used in both questionnaires. The score of the positive explicit affect scale in full version of the questionnaire will be calculated as a mean of happy, cheerful and energetic moods.  The score of the negative explicit affect scale will be calculated as a mean of helpless, tense and inhibited moods.
registration_responses.q19.question:
The following analyses will be performed:
•	Bivariate correlation coefficients for the positive affect scales of the following pairs of measures: the IPANAT and the DMM-M, the IPANAT (short) and the DMM-M (short) , the IPANAT and the IPANAT (short), the DMM-M and the DMM-M (short), explicit affect and the IPANAT, explicit affect and the DMM-M, explicit affect (short) and the IPANAT (short), explicit affect and the DMM-M (short), explicit affect and explicit affect (short). 
•	Bivariate correlation coefficients for negative affect scales of the same pairs of measures.
•	Regressions with short measure as independent variable and full measure as dependent variable to determine what percentage of variance in full measure is explained by variance in a short measure (one regression for each of the following: the IPANAT positive affect scale, the IPANAT negative affect scale, the DMM-M positive affect scale, the DMM-M negative affect scale, the measure of the explicit negative affect and the measure of explicit positive affect).
•	Cronbach’s alpha for positive affect scale and negative affect scale for each of the four implicit measures.

q3.value: We are looking at the effects of Personal Vision on Information Elaboration and thus Team Performance.

q4.value: The model that we are proposing is Personal Vision leads to Information Elaboration, which leads to Team Performance. Potential mechanisms for Personal Vision to Information Elaboration are Psychological Distance, Dehumanization, Interpersonal Respect, Categorization Tendency, Bias, Lowered Inclusion, and Psychological Safety. Potential moderators are Team Diversity and VUCA (volatility, uncertainty, complexity, ambiguity).

attributes.title: First-Generation Students: Sense of Community, Impostor Phenomenon, and Subjective Happiness

q1.value: First-Generation Students: Sense of Community, Impostor Phenomenon, and Subjective Happiness

q3.value: The purpose of this study is to investigate the relationship among sense of community, impostor phenomenon, and subjective happiness for first-generation university students who attend York University. Our goal is to understand the experiences of first-generation students at York University, with the further aim of identifying unique needs and resources for this population of students. Research will be conducted via online surveys and in-person focus groups.

q4.value: We predict a moderate effect of generational status on Sense of Community, Impostor Phenomenon, and Subjective Happiness. We predict that first-generation status will result in moderately lower Sense of Community and Subjective Happiness and moderately higher Imposter Phenomenon.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Between-subjects, mixed methods design. For the between-subjects portion we essentially have three different 1 factor, 2 level studies (generational status vs each of the three constructs).

We will recruit students from both the undergraduate and graduate levels at York University. Undergraduate students will be recruited from 1000 and 2000 level Psychology courses using the Undergraduate Research Participation Pool in Psychology. Graduate students will be recruited for participation through social media, specifically LinkedIn (see Appendix A), an email from the Psychology Graduate Office (see Appendix B), and advertisments posted within and around the Psychology Department (see Appendix C). We aim to recruit approximately 100 participants (80 undergraduate students, 20 graduate students). 

Average scores will be calculated and compared for Sense of Community, Subjective Happiness, and Impostor Phenomenon for both first-generation students and continuing-generation students. This data will be collected via online surveys. We will run three t-tests comparing generational status (first generation and continuing generation) to each of the three construct scores. Thus, there will be three independent 1 factor, 2 level analyses.

Focus groups will also be used to explore the experiences of first-generation students further.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: Students have started to complete the surveys but none of the researchers have viewed this data.

question.value: Undergraduate and graduate students will be recruited during mid-January 2020 for survey participation. Undergraduate students will be recruited via URPP. Graduate students will be recruited via social media (LinkedIn; see Appendix A) and an email communication from the Psychology Graduate Office (see Appendix B). Students will be directed to a Qualtrics survey link. Prior to completing the surveys, students will complete an online informed consent script (see Appendix D). On Qualtrics, students will complete a set of four brief surveys: (1) demographics (see Appendix E); (2) Brief Scale of Sense of Community (BSCS; see Appendix F) (Peterson, Speer, & McMillan, 2008); (3) Clance Impostor Phenomenon Scale (CIPS; see Appendix G) (Clance, 1985); and (4) Subjective Happiness Scale (SHS; see Appendix H) (Lyubomirsky & Lepper, 1999). Completion of all surveys will take appoximately 15 minutes. The demographic survey (see Appendix E) includes items such as age, year of study, race, and identified gender. We also include an option for students to provide their email should they wish to participate in a follow-up focus group. Undergraduate students will be informed that providing their email is not required for participation in the survey portion of the study alone, and that they are not required to participate in the focus group in order to receive partial course credit. Please note that we will be asking students to report some personal information, such as their race, identified gender, and use of academic accomodations on the demographic survey. The purpose of these questions is to gather information on how these variables may moderate the relationship among sense of community, impostor phenomenon, and generational status; i.e., they are variables of interest. We have worked to develop appropriate and sensitive wording for these items. For both of these questions, students are also provided with an option to withhold a response. The Brief Sense of Community Scale (BSCS; see Appendix F) is an 8-item questionnaire that was developed to measure the sense of community dimensions of needs fulfillment, group membership, influence, and shared emotional connection within a specified community (Peterson, Speer, & McMillan, 2008). The BSCS is validated for assessement of sense of community (Peterson et al., 2008). The Clance Impostor Phenomenon Scale (CIPS; see Appendix G) is a 20-item questionnaire that measures impostor phenomenon (Clance, 1985). The scale has been shown to reliably differentiate those experiencing impostor phenomemon and those who are not (Chrisman, Pieper, Clance, Holland, & Glickauf-Hughes, 1995). The Subjective Happiness Scale (SHS; see Appendix H) is a 4-item measure of global subjective happiness, as measured through self-evaluation, which has been validated in 14 studies and over 2700 participants (Lyubomirsky & Lepper, 1999). FOCUS GROUP PARTICIPATION: When survey data collection is complete, students who have indicated interest in focus participation will be contacted via email. We will offer them the opportunity to participate in a focus group in exchange for a chance to win a Starbucks gift card via a draw (see Appendix I for email script, Appendix J for focus group informed consent, and Appendix K for focus group questions). These participants will be contacted via email (see Appendix I) and provided with potential focus group time slots. When participants have indicated their preferred time, focus group(s) will be scheduled. We will also post advertisments in and around the Psychology department recruiting for the focus groups (see Appendix C). We anticipate holding 1-3 focus groups depending on response rate and scheduling. Focus groups will take place in the Behavioural Science Building and be moderated by Julie Conder. Dr. Conder will explain the focus group procedure, letting participants know that the session will be recorded, that their anonymity is ensured, and how data will be securely stored. If participants agree, they will sign an informed consent prior to the focus group (see Appendix J). Recordings of focus group sessions will be subsequently transcribed. Participants will only be identified on transcripts via their initials.

q13.value: We aim to recruit approximately 100 participants (80 undergraduate students, 20 graduate students).

q14.value: We conducted a power analysis (G-POWER) with the goal of obtaining .8 power to detect a medium effect size of 0.5 at the standard .05 alpha error probability. This gave us a sample size of approx 28 for each group.

q15.value: We will terminate data collection near the end of March 2020 to allow for sufficient data analysis time for Poster Day.

question.value: N/A - observational study.

We will measure a variety of variables on a demographics form. The primary variable of interest on this form is generational status (first generation vs continuing generation). We will also measure three constructs: Sense of Community, Impostor Phenomenon, and Subjective Happiness. The constructs will be measured using 3 different tools that were designed and used in previous studies.

We will be calculating the mean scores for each of the three constructs (Sense of Community, Impostor Phenomenon, and Subjective Happiness) for each level of generational status (2 levels - first-generation and continuing-generation). We will be comparing the mean scores for each construct (between generational status) using a 1-directional 2-sample t-test analysis.
We will perform 3 1-tailed independent t-tests to determine if there is a significant difference between the two generational statuses and the three constructs.

q21.value: We will perform 3 1-tailed independent t-tests to determine if there is a significant difference between the two generational statuses and the three constructs.

q24.value: We will be conducting focus groups and collecting a range of demographics information which we will use to look for unspecified differences or relationships.

attributes.title: Drug resistance in acute phase of HIV patients with ART-naive：a systematic review and meta-analysis

q1.value: Drug resistance in acute phase of HIV patients with ART-naive：a systematic review and meta-analysis

q2.value: Chunxiang Guo, Yang Zhang, Aixin Li, Meixia Gao, Ke Zhang, Shui Jiang, Tong Zhang, Hao Wu, Xiaojie Huang, Guanzhi Chen

q3.value: The treatment of HIV patients has always been a topic of public concern. With the proposal of antiviral treatment(ART), many AIDS patients have benefited, at the same time, the emergence of drug resistance has also become an important aspect that can not be ignored.Previous studies have mostly tested drug resistance in patients with chronic infection or patients with failed virological inhibition.The emergence of drug resistance results in a waste of medical resources, so it is necessary to routinely detect drug resistance in patients with HIV before antiviral treatment.Therefore, we studied the drug resistance rate and mutation of acute HIV infection without ART.

q4.value: People infected with HIV in acute phase are highly contagious, and different kinds of drug resistance may exist before receiving ART.We speculate that the rate of resistance to nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) and non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTIs) in patients with acute HIV infection without antiretroviral therapy(ART) was high, but the resistance rate to integrase inhibitors(INIs) was low，and the mutation rate of protease inhibitors(PIs) was high, but the actual drug resistance rate was low.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We identified studies published up to Dec. 30, 2019,through systematic literature searches and discussion with investigators.In this systematic review and meta-analysis,we performed a comprehensive database searching in PubMed, Web of Science,Embase and the Cochrane Library,and were done with medical subject headings and free text relating to“AIDS”OR“HIV”,“early infection”OR“acute infection”OR“primary infection”OR“early HIV infection”OR“acute HIV infection”OR“primary HIV infection”AND“resistance”OR“TDR”OR“PDR”, in English language.There are no research type restrictions on the studies we included.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: The studies we included had to be ART-naive patients with acute, early or primary HIV infected . Study selection criteria only original studies were considered,review articles were excluded.The inclusion criteria for studies were that they were cross-sectional, case control, or cohort in design.The investigators measured one or more NNRTIs,NRTIs,PIs,INSTIs,FIs mutation and their respective mutation sites.The exclusion criteria are studies of people infected with HIV who have received antiretroviral therapy and those who are not in the acute phase of HIV infection.

q13.value: 15 studies published up to Dec. 30, 2019 met inclusion criteria and were included in the review. A total of 5048 participants were enrolled in these studies.The year of sample collection is from July 1, 1995.

question.value: The investigators measured any of the following outcomes:1.Drug resistance rates to NRTI, NNRTI, PI and INSTI, respectively.2.Types of drug resistant mutations to different reverse  inhibitors.

Statistical calculations were performed using Excel version 2019(16.0.12430.20112, Microsoft).
Statistical analysis was done in Stata SE.We used the Newcastle-Ottawa Quality Assessment Scale of the non-randomized trial and the observational study to evaluate the bias quality and risk of the included study.For pooled data, the I² statistic was used to estimate heterogeneity and risk of bias, specifically publication bias.

q22.value: We will exclude studies that do not extract the required data.
